ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Good lab to understand and ground concepts learned in lecture
I learned some interesting concepts but in all honesty I did not gain much from this course. It was VERY stressful and time consuming.
How to develop an at-home physics experiment, collect data, run analysis with LoggerPro, and form conclusions
Concepts of waves, electronics, magnetism, and optics. How to take proper lab notes, and compile a concise and coherent lab report.

I gained an appreciation for the real world applications of concepts of electricity and optics, which proved extremely helpful during the more theoretical lecture course when we covered the same material at a later date.

I learned a lot of interesting physics concepts that were also relevant to the course material I was learning in PHYS181, and I also got to see videos of interesting hands-on experiments showing important equipment for these concepts. I also learned how to write in my lab notebook and also construct polished reports.
knowledge of circuits and physics concepts/machinery, writing lab reports, designing experiments
I developed a deeper understanding of concepts in electricity and magnetism, some of which I had never seen before. I became more comfortable with taking lab notes and writing lab reports.

Basic signal analysis and use of Fourier transforms. Circuit design, behavior of circuit elements (resistors, capacitors, inductors), transients in RLC circuits. One lab each devoted to introductory geometric optics (thin lens and Snell's) and physical optics (thin slit diffraction patterns).
General physics laboratory skills
Physics concepts and lab techniques
I learned how to analyze data, apply the concepts taught in class, and perform hands-on experiments to test my understanding.
This semester, Physics Lab focused on the concepts of waves, light, circuits, etc.
I learned the basic concepts of physics including electricity and magnetism, circuits, and light behavior. I also developed the skills of the scientific research process.
Concepts specific to normal things you learn in a physics II lab. Like E & M, optics, etc.

This course allowed me to explore how light behaves at boundary interfaces and through mediums, how charge, capacitance, and resistance are related within a circuit, and finally how a fourier transform can provide information on sine waves and the fundamental frequencies within a compound wave.
a lot of fourier series stuff, some circuit/optics

(virtual) familiarization with oscilloscopes, physical familizarization with pocket-sized multimeters and circuits. Concepts included: Ampere's Law, Ohm's Law, Fourier transformations to characterize waves, damped harmonic motion, basic optics, etc.
General physics 2 knowledge.
I learned how some of the theory in PHYS 181 is applied in a lab setting.
Not much honestly.
Learned how to better write lab reports and conduct experiments as well as design my own
Applications of physics in the laboratory setting.
I gained insight into how to design experiments when given a specific problem.
Basic physics concepts were applied and learned through watching virtual videos.
How to practically test and experiment with physical principles
I learned basic physics labs skills
A cursory knowledge of introductory physics and laboratory techniques.
How to communicate with other lab students virtually as well as use lab equipment virtually.
I learned how to problem solve and follow directions closely.
Physics
Wave functions, optics, etx
Critical thinking.
I learned how to conduct physics experiment and use LoggerPro.

I learned how to use equipment like oscilloscopes, function generators, and different circuits. I also developed knowledge in the topics of simple and complex signals, capacitors and charge, induction and RLC circuits, geometric optics, and diffraction.
I think that PHYS 166L taught me how to think critically and approach scientific problems from multiple angles.
physics lab skills in electricity and magnetism
I learned about Physics topics such as Circuits and Optics while also gained exposure to lab tools and equipment.
Uncertainty, the basics of experimental design with simple harmonic motion, electricity, and optics
I learned a lot of basic principles of physics which were reinforced by doing simulations online and using the kits that we were provided.
I gained a practical understanding of how electronic signals can be analyzed by FFT.
I learned about topics such as circuits, optics, and beat frequencies. I also learned how to design my own experiment modelling the experiments that we have seen in class.

I learned about Fourier transform, optics, electricity, and magnetism. I developed skills in using LoggerPro for physics experiments. I learned about data analysis and critical thinking about physics experiments.
I learned a lot more about practical applications of electricity/magnetism and other important physics concepts. I also became more familiar with data analysis and collecting good data.
I learned a lot more about electricity and magnetism.
I further developed my lab skills.
Went very in depth about oscillators and electromagnetism, with some optics at the end.
I don't think I learned that much in this course, besides how to rush through a lab handout during lab section.
How to write a proper lab reports, topics of physics in a lab environment.
physics lab skills - E&M
Applications of electromagnetism, geometric optics
This class taught me many basics of circuits and their components, how to use various tools to measure quantities of circuits and signals, as well as some basic theories surrounding light waves.
Learned physics through practical lab experiences. Learned about circuits, capacitors, inductors, and optics through lab demonstrations.
How to use pokitmeter and logger pro.
Basic lab for physics in electricity and magnetism
I learned a lot about the applications of physics concepts. The labs were fun and interesting.
Deeper understanding of electricity, magnetism, and optics at fundamental level, but with emphasis on mastering trends and patterns that explain and predict phenomena.
I learned physics concepts through the use of LoggerPro and other lab applications.
Got to learn some physics in action stuff. Explored various physics topics.

I learned how to operate common lab equipment such as oscilloscopes and multimeters. The course also helped solidify my understanding of the real world implications of the concepts learned in my physics course. More specifically, this course helped me better understand the behavior of circuits and other electrical systems.
To be honest, I did not learn much.
Scientific methodology, various physical principles, precise and accurate experimental setup and measurements.
i learned about the devices used in physics experimentation historically and currently to analyze data relating to signals, electricity, magnetism, and light
I learned how to apply PHYS 181 lecture topics to virtual lab experiments.
Physics lab principles and analysis
I investigated and learned about the practical basis of topics such as magnetism, electrostatics, circuits, lenses, sound waves, and capacitors, among other topics.

I wrote a lot for the labs, so I felt like the greatest gained skill was summarizing lab procedures in my notebook and churning out a conclusion. Also, we worked with a lot of data. In general, I also gained an understanding of the physics of electricity, light, waves, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
Strengths - some concepts were interesting
Weakness - very long zoom session, felt like a lot of pointless work, kits were pointless, very stressful, harsh grading every now and then
PLAs were graded harshly; maybe indicate expectations another time? 166L also felt a bit harder compared to 165L in terms of the conceptual part of understanding the lab but that may be just me.
Strengths: The course was put together very well. The best possible experience for a virtual lab.

Strengths: easy to navigate and does not demand or consume too much of your time. Weakness: grading is fairly subjective and based on your TA, and feedback from labs was not given in a timely manner. We received feedback on our PLAs after all of them had been completed, and points had been taken off for the same things on multiple reports (something that could have been fixed in later assignments had the feedback been given earlier).

This course was very effective in promoting the interpretation of equations and the meaning of the various variables therein, but it often felt as though the equations themselves, as well as the experiments used to demonstrate their applicability, were simply invented from whole cloth, and had no application outside of the narrow realm of basic science pertaining to electricity or optics. The hands-on component with the kits was often equally frustrating, as concepts which had seemed so simple and fundamental in the course videos proved extremely difficult to recreate in real life without any guidance.
Strengths: This course was set up in a way so that students had plenty of opportunities to ask questions to their TFs and get the help they need to work through each of the labs.

strengths: manageable workload for assignments, low stakes if got things wrong, geared towards learning
weaknesses: had to do experiments without knowledge of concepts sometimes
areas for improvement: more instruction

I really appreciate that the instructors seemed responsive to student feedback, and that the policies in this course were clear and did not cause me any unnecessary stress. One way this course could be improved is if it did not occasionally run ahead of my non-lab physics course. However, I appreciate the detailed explanations in the lab handouts, which I'm sure were made with this in mind.
Given the circumstances I felt that this course was structured well. I appreciated having the kits to do the PLAs, and also only having either a lab or a PLA each week but not both was very helpful.

Strengths: I think I learned more from this course than my actual physics course. The lab handouts were so well written and clear. Weaknesses: This class was SO much work. I understand that a virtual lab is very difficult but honestly it was hard to learn this way. I hope they won't have to do online again.
This course ran much more smoothly than PHYS 165L. Not having a PLA every week was way less overwhelming.

Strengths: The teaching staff really catered to their students' needs. Specifically, Professor Barrett and Professor Cahn were very understanding and prioritized their students' learning and well-being. They designed the course in a way that facilitated learning but also considered the challenges evoked by the current pandemic. Every time I spoke with Professor Cahn, he was able to clarify my concerns and explain the concepts in a way that was easy to understand. The lab videos were fun and engaging due to Professor Cahn's enthusiasm and love for teaching. 

Weaknesses: Perhaps Professor Cahn could hold weekly office hours. My TA wasn't great at explaining lab concepts, so I often had to schedule a meeting with another Professor to fully understand the labs.

The course material was hard to understand because a lot of it was not introduced in lecture. The TA also did not give good explanations on what we should understand before doing the lab. Also, the PLAs did very little to further my understandings of the material covered in lab.
The labs are fun and informative. There is no weakness of this course.
They got better by the end of the term, but some of the beginning labs were far too long for the time scale. I did like the PLAs where you could experiment by yourself though.
Actually loved the PLAs. They took a while but I feel like I learned the most by doing them. Keep doing those, I'd say

As the course was online, it was difficult to connect with peers if there were questions that arose after lab ended. Additionally, being on zoom for 3 hours was very draining. However, the class was very well formatted for online learning and easy to follow. Prof. Barrett was incredibly helpful and very excited to teach, as was my TA.
I think the labs were very interesting and I learned a decent amount, but the post-lab assignments (PLAs) didn't help much in understanding the material.

by nature of virtual labs, the labs were much less engaging as it largely consisted of watching videos of someone else do a lab; this also made the labs much easier imo; fewer but more engaging post-lab activities (compared to PHYS 165) which I liked
Seems like a solid curriculum with a solid staff. Would be better in-person.
I think the lab focuses too much on format and less on getting a good understanding of the physical concepts. I think a better balance could be struck between the two.
The PLAs being cut back was great because I learned something, yet didnt feel too overwhelmed by the material
It's a lot of work/writing esp for a virtual semester where we can't actually do the labs.

weaknesses - lab handouts were often long and convoluted, was sometimes hard to get adequate help due to  zoom  formatting, but really  appreciate the  effort all the teaching staff put in to help us!
There weren't any significant strengths nor weaknesses of this course.
Requirements for lab reports wasn't super clear at first but otherwise, the course was well-organized and executed
This course was not taught well. You basically were given a lab manual to follow, nothing taught nor explained to you. Had to figure out everything on your own.
I believe that in person labs will be better than online learning, but this lab format still did well despite this weakness.
The strength of the course is the professors, they know what they are doing and are willing to help.
The professors and TFs were every engaged in trying to conduct this course to the best of their abilities. For a virtual lab, theres only so much one can do to provide the actual experience.

Strengths: very personable professors
Weaknesses: none really.
The PLAs were very good!

This was without a doubt one of the most well-run and taught courses I've ever taken at Yale, and in STEM no less. Everything about this course was great, with the one exception that I wish it aligned better with the physics lectures, but this was not a constant problem.
Strengths: zoom format meant not too much work or tedious time stuff
I really liked this course and the virtual format.

Strengths: very good pace of learning, very accommodating towards everyone
Weaknesses: some difficulty in communication/participation due to virtual nature
This was a rough course to take remotely. It needs to move back to in person.
Its recorded videos, weak. Content and Professor Cahn strong

the professors in this course were a definite strength of this course; you could tell all of them cared very deeply in teaching the students about physics laboratory skills and it showed in every lab handout.

Strengths: adjusted well to online format
Area of improvement: the lab hand outs could be written much more clearly
I definitely enjoyed how interactive the labs are and I appreciated how the teaching team adapted the labs for a virtual format.

Strengths : professors enthusiasm and dedication
Weakness: disparity in tas

Strengths: instructors and TF were very helpful and easily available, encouraged working with peers since we always had a constant lab partner and then were rotated to work with a different lab group each week, grading was pretty quick and straightforward, no final exam, we were allowed to skip one PLA when it was our break day, pre-lab quizzes were pretty straightforward, professors communicated very frequently and organization of the class was pretty clear 

Weaknesses: lab handouts were often confusingly worded and even my TF was often a little confused as to what they were asking, some labs felt really repetitive in terms of constantly watching videos and then plugging numbers into LoggerPro, lab notes are extremely tedious
I think the professors made the most of the difficult situation this semester.  Not ideal to be taking a lab online but I still feel like I got something out of it.
The workload made it hard to stay engaged and curious
This course did very well with organization and keeping the students informed about the course. I don't have any improvements for this course.

Strength: the enthusiasm of most of the instructors and TAs are unparalleled! They really try to make it entertaining and flexible for a wide background of students

Weakness: Well, the experiments are pre-recorded this year so the students really did not do much hands-on work, sometimes it felt like there did not need to be a synchronous portion at all. Though I would also agree that this was made a lot easier than having to set up the experiments by ourselves in person.
I think the lab was generally well organized and geared towards learning.
I thought the course was generally too much per laboratory session and the TA was unhelpful. I thought its strength lied in the take-home practical activities.

It is hard to administer a lab online, but I think that watching the videos during class and getting to plan a post lab assignment ourselves after class really makes up for the lack of hands on learning that comes with a virtual lab. I think the class is well planned out and structured, and the expectations was very clear from the beginning.

The course taught a lot of different aspects of electricity and magnetism, which gave a broad view of the field. The course provided ways to work with data, so we can explore certain concepts first-hand. The teaching team was very receptive to changes and questions. With that said, sometimes the material seemed beyond the scope of the class, and it may take a couple of weeks to fully understand the material (like Fourier transform). The post-lab activities did not feel like it added very much to the learning experience. Sometimes the labs were quite long and couldn't be finished during the session, so there are certain parts of the lab I did not fully understand.
Strengths: Instructors are super involved and helpful, and really want to help you learn!! Lab reports can be somewhat tedious though.

Strengths: The way the instructors changed up the course this semester to reflect a lighter workload was extremely considerate and made the course more enjoyable for me. I felt like I could complete the assignments and still feel engaged with the content instead of just submitting assignments nonstop.

The strengths of this course is that the assignments were fair, had good grading, and really were structured to help us learn. Also, being able to work in groups was very helpful. Also, the TF's and professors were all very supportive.
I think that we missed some content by only having an actual lab every other week (due to the break days).

strengths- professors we're fun and engaging
weaknesses- lab handouts we're sometimes disorganized and confusing

The instructors worked incredibly hard to make this course a positive experience during this semester. Overall, I think the course was organized well, but the labs around the middle of the semester were often excessively long and it felt like there were portions that were a bit repetitive. I do really appreciate how much care went into the course though! 

Also, it was frustrating that points were taken off on the labs due to small non-conceptual errors (ie. showing work for simple steps). The overall grading scheme in this course is difficult since most students do very well on labs, so even minor deductions can lead to a less-than-desired curved grade. One way to get around this would be to grade the write-ups (the one page summaries) more harshly, which I think would actually benefit the students by rewarding those who put in the time, even if they may have made a few small errors in their lab notes.

Wish it was 1 credit!!
This class, in my opinion, was very poorly set up. I don't think the virtual labs were helpful in learning any actual physics, but understand that there were few options with COVID.
strengths: very helpful and understanding teaching team

strengths: the kits were helpful for COVID, the videos and resources were very thoughtful

weaknesses: this class is very difficult to teach online - hopefully it can be taught in person next semester
Strengths: instructors obviously cared a lot about students, feedback was clear, PLAs were a good compromise and helped recreate some semblance of normalcy

This class was helpful in how it gave me a somewhat hands-on experience working with components of circuits and the tools to record measurements. However, sometimes it fell out of sync with the corresponding lecture, which made it harder to understand what was being discussed in the background.

Strengths: the professors and instructors are very supportive, and are always eager to help students. Instructors try to make demonstrations, lab handouts, etc. as understandable and engaging as possible, without compromising the quality of the material. The course did suffer from being a virtual lab, since the students were unable to perform most of the experiments, but the instructors tried their best to make up for this via take-home lab materials and activities, which were interesting.
The videos and assignments were very well though out and detailed. It helped me learn a lot of the concepts well. The sindeYkits were very fun to use and I am glad they were implemented.

Strength was much higher flexibility and administrative care than last semester.  This sequence was a huge success because it took all the short comings of last semester and combined them with the high points.  Great care was taken to not make the same mistakes twice and the instructor level teamwork was phenomenal.  
Only weakness was having all the supplies takes up volume, but it was a necessary tradeoff to staying virtual.

This class did not align with Physics 171 coursework very well. I did not feel that there was much support from staff during lab hours. The PLAs were a nice break from Zoom lab during break weeks, but they were actually quite time consuming.

I really appreciated the weekly emails from the lab professors and Professor Cahn's kit delivery, though.
Definitely harder online but they adapted it pretty well. Course was interesting and a fine lab course.
I think that this course was as good as can be expected from a virtual lab course. It was easy to get help during the labs and labs were modified well to accommodate the virtual environment.

The strengths of this course definitely included the instructors, TAs, and their willingness to engage with us through a difficult online semester. It is my own fault for not engaging with the course enough.

The strength is the lab design. the labs did help students explore the concepts from the physics lecture series. The weaknesses are the instruction (and the boundaries crossed by instructors), the lack of respect for student time, and the confusing nature of the PLA assignments.

Compared to last semester, there was more transparency. There were a lot more reminders and information being sent out constantly on how the course is progressing and what all we need to do or be on the lookout for. A weakness would be the lack of collaboration within a breakout room. While it was not completely silent, cameras off, muted, it was somewhat difficult to collaborate with the Zoom format since the labs could be mostly done by oneself, so everyone's pacing is different.
While in person learning would've been much better, this course was optimized for online learning and the efforts made by the course heads were appropriate and effective.
plas were stressful and annoying - the weeks that were plas should've just been break weeks for everyone

A strength was the organization and clarity of the lab handouts. It was somewhat tedious and hard to focus when the labs were extremely long but the second half of the semester was much better than the first. I also appreciated how they accommodated our break weeks with a smaller workload.
Standard lab course; curve was quite harsh

Weaknesses: stupid grading scale. This class was curved downwards at the very last minute because too many people scored As and high scores. This was such that someone who scored a 95% received an A- and 93% received a B+, etc. To improve the class, do not do this and invalidate students' hard-earned scores.

A major strength of this course was the flexibility, especially with the lack of labs during break weeks, allowing a bit of a reprieve every so often. I don't think the course itself had many weaknesses, but there were sometimes where the answer to a certain part of the lab or conceptual bases for experiments wasn't always clear, making it hard to complete the experiment.

Strengths: learning science, the DIY labs were also fun and some of the most learning I did.
Weaknesses: it did get kind of stale and repetitive after a while of looking at the lab steps and then following the directions.

This class was pretty terrible. It was so repetitive, and labs crammed in so much stuff that it was all about getting it done rather than learning. This semester there was certainly less busy work than phys 165L which was a major improvement, but the labs themselves were much worse, and much more boring.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: It is difficult to conduct a lab over a series of videos and online and feel like I got a whole lot out of it.
PLAs on the break weeks (instead of at the same time as normal labs) was a huge improvement from last semester. Overall did a great job.

The virtual lab activities were for the most part fairly simply laid out, though in some cases the proscriptions necessary to complete them seemed arbitrary, with no basis in prior work. The lab videos for the course started out just as engaging and interesting as last semester, but by the end were serving to actively lower my engagement. The virtual lectures at the start of lab were rarely useful in any real sense, and felt cursory. The mandatory use of the kits in a highly unstructured manner often led to dead ends and frustration, as it felt as if we were provided no support but expected to generate results on par with those created in the highly structured lab environment.
Succeeded: plenty of opportunities to communicate with the TF and ask questions, plenty of opportunities for group work with lab partners

succeeded: DIY experiments
needs improvement: making the lab videos more engaging

I think that as far as virtual labs go, this course was as good as it could have been. The videos, breakout rooms, lab handouts, and Logger Pro data all worked well for me. I think it was very well done. I feel that I do lack knowledge of what to do in a physical lab. However, I think this is owing to the virtual format, and the intructors did a good job of trying to make up for this by providing us with great opportunities to have hands-on experiences using our lab kits. I just chose not to take advantage of them because there were easier alternative assignments.

I thought that the virtual labs were pretty effective at replicating the in-person experience, but obviously you learn more when a lab is hands-on. Occasionally, the setup was not entirely clear, so I might have appreciated different angled videos, more photographs, or things like that to appreciate what was physically going on. I enjoyed the post-lab activities more than I expected, although my self-directed learning wasn't the most efficient.
Having the kits and doing the PLAs was very helpful for virtual engagement.
I think we could've just made it asynchronous and had students content their TA if they had questions. Doing it synchronously through zoom just felt like a waste of time.
I feel like the pre-recorded lab videos were the best possible solution among practices geared towards learning during the pandemic.

I appreciated that the professors decided to mail out physics lab equipment to us so that we may do the labs ourselves. However, because there was very little guidance about how to use the equipment, and it was much faster and beneficial for us to choose a virtual PLA option, I did not interact with the physical equipment very much at all this semester.
The physics kits for at home exploration were fun and helpful but not super necessary
Although nothing can replace face to face interactions, the use of zoom and prerecorded videos was really effective for someone who is enrolled online.

Overall the transition to online was good. Getting SidKits was annoying though. The distribution wasn't well planned, and it was at very random times so if you didn't check your email fast enough it didn't work. In general, the videos were good and helpful, but a couple were unclear.

PLAs were lovely and helped me learn the material best. It was hard to truly understand circuits, however, just by watching them. Which isn't the fault of the teachers or anything. It's just more difficult to do that over zoom.

The well written out lab hand-out was wonderful and easy to follow. Having all the relevant videos well organized and all the folders on canvas were properly labeled was incredible. It was easy to know where class materials were located and how to access them. 
However, I wonder if it would have been more helpful to do the lab on your own (during the allotted lab period) And then to meet for 30 minutes after lab to check answers and address any questions.
virtual labs just aren't as engaging as in-person labs; instructors did what they could given the circumstances

This is a very difficult class to make virtual, since all of the activities are intended to be hands-on. They did the best that they could, but there is no question that the virtual version simply cannot compare to the in-person lab. The videos of the professors performing the experiments were somewhat effective, but I never walked away feeling as though I could reproduce what they did just by observation. Hopefully the only advice that this course would need would be to return to in-person.
Great TA engagement during lab
This class was phenomenal in adapting to the pandemic format. The break day format was incredible and made engaging with the PLAs that much more enjoyable.
The virtual labs were helpful for learning and the PLAs helped strengthen my understanding of the labs.
The PLAs were a waste of time. They did not improve understanding of the course material.
Although it was to aid students go through each steps of the lab with their lab TFs, the "virtual lab" sessions seemed very awkward, with most people having their cameras and mics turned off.
Splitting the labs between live and at-home made for a nice mix of different experiments and possibilities
The recorded videos simply didn't have the same learning impact as actually performing them in person.
It transitioned very well. The PLA every other week was a great idea.
The PLAs were very good! It was nice to have a chance to explore topics of personal interest this semester that wouldn't have been covered in a normal semester.
Labs could be a bit shorter
I think having everyone in one room instead of breakout rooms would have been better.
It was a difficult course to learn from virtually due to the normally hands-on nature of it.
Very grateful with how accommodating the teaching staff was with extending deadlines and responding to student concerns
The flexibility/off-days were helpful. The actual labs were difficult to do online and turned into busy work sometimes.
Recorded lectures did not work

Success: not doing a final exam, allowing collaboration in break out rooms, etc 

Improvement: more clear lab handouts (they are sometimes convoluted) and also make the quizzes open note
The labs were actually very clear compared to what I expected (due to virtual format).

I thought the use of smaller breakout rooms each week helped with engagement since I felt more comfortable speaking when there were fewer people and this allowed people to work at their own pace more. I also liked that Professor Urry and my TF would frequently pop in to check if we had any questions. It was often hard to come up with ideas for the PLA at first, but I do think that they helped with pushing me to engage with the topics more since it forced me to evaluate what I knew and didn't know.
The kits provided to us were very helpful. They included a variety of instruments and materials that allowed us to have the most hands-on experience possible with this online format.
virtual lab was nice in the fact that it was every other week but the break week assignments were grueling
Communication and organization succeeded. Breaking up into small discussion sections was very helpful.

Strength: the enthusiasm of most of the instructors and TAs are unparalleled! They really try to make it entertaining and flexible for a wide background of students. They specifically implemented "Post Lab Activities" especially for weeks with 'break day' and on one hand they can be very creative and students really take learning into their own hands, on the other end, they are always more time consuming than described in the syllabus/assignment or even as anticipated ny students (the later ones with suggest activities/more guidance was helpful). 

Weakness: Well, the experiments are pre-recorded this year so the students really did not do much hands-on work, sometimes it felt like there did not need to be a synchronous portion at all. Though I would also agree that this was made a lot easier than having to set up the experiments by ourselves in person.
I thought sending home the SIndey kits was a really lovely idea, but the actual lab classes where we split into groups were very difficult to stay focused.

I think that switching from having a post lab assignment and the lab reports due separate weeks really helped to space out the workload. In addition, not having lab on the week of the break day and using that time to work on the post lab assignment instead was really helpful and considerate given the situation that we are in.

The breakout room format was very effective. We got to interact with students to work on the lab. The TF rotating around to breakout rooms was extremely helpful as we always got our questions efficiently answered. The format of having lab sections on weeks with no break days and post-lab activities (PLA) on weeks with break days made lab less stressful compared to Phys 165L. LoggerPro and videos was the best they could given the pandemic, so at least we could learn and analyze actual data. I did not find the post-lab activities to be a particularly useful learning experience as I often had inaccurate data collected or spent a lot of time thinking about what to do and if I had the materials to complete the PLA.

I enjoyed being able to do post-lab assignments on my own time and that we did not have live sessions during the weeks when we had break days. It gave us a bit more flexibility to work according to how our schedules worked out easiest.

To combat the issue of excessively long labs, perhaps students should be allowed to "finish" the lab at the end of the allotted time, and simply make a note in their lab notebook that they didn't fully get through the last section or so. Assuming that students only utilized this within reason, this could help make the course structure a bit better.
i enjoyed the modification to PLA weeks for the spring semester. it was a lot easier to handle than last semester when we had to do a PLA and a normal lab all in the same week
it is very difficult to teach this class on zoom, but the kit and virtual resources were helpful.

Succeeded: recorded labs (for the most part), PLAs 


Failed: I think the labs were MUCH clearer and more engaging last semester (ie phys 165L). This semester, a lot of the work we did felt like busy work and the labs often drastically varied in length. Going into the lab, you wouldn't know if it was going to take you 45 min or >5 hrs. Last semester, the labs were much more consistent and the relevance of what we were doing better explained.

This lab class was difficult to track sometimes because at some points simply watching videos was not enough to allow me to truly grasp the concepts. The post lab activities worked well at helping me reinforce lab ideas better.

Virtual lab sections and online video demos were fair; they communicated the material clearly. Physics lab as a whole suffered from the virtual format (not the instructor's fault, this was just by nature), but the instructors tried their best to make up for this in a variety of ways, including trying to describe what would happen in-person, shipping hands-on lab materials for out-of-lab activities, etc.
The adjustment made to the assignment workload this semester compared to PHYS 165L in the previous COVID-19 virtual semester was so much better!
I felt as though the breakout sessions to work in smaller groups helped facilitate learning. The TAs were all very helpful as well.
The very understanding extension system and the asynchronous weeks were extremely successful and useful.  This course set a high standard which emphasized learning over fighting deadlines!

This semester had a more balanced workload than last semester (by having PLAs and no Zoom during break weeks). However, I never really felt comfortable with the conceptual material while completing the labs. I think the introductions could definitely use some work.
I think it was run just about as well as it could be online. The postlab activities during break weeks worked well and were an interesting way to explore the concepts.

I think that the adaptation of the labs for a virtual format was very successful, as all the information and demonstrations were conveyed in a clear and interesting way. The at home portion of the course (PLA labs) was helpful for getting more hands on with the course material, but the suggested areas to explore lacked variety towards the middle of the semester.

This course was a rare example of a course that was better online. the strength of this course is that the online format allowed convenience and flexibility for an otherwise tedious requirement. The choice this semester to only have PLAs on the weeks when there were no labs was better than the first semester. The PLAs were also more interesting than the ones we completed first semester. However, the PLAs are incredibly time consuming. In order to do an experiment that would earn us full points, we needed to put in significantly more time htan instructors seemed to understand. I was spending upwards of 6 hours on each PLA. This was what was necessary in order to get enough on the page to get full credit. In addition, the expectations for the PLA were completely unclear, and with TAs that often were more than a month and a half behind on grading, it wasn't sufficient to be expected to wait for feedback on previous assignments. (I had actually completed all of the PLAs before I got feedback on the second one). In addition, the sindykits were completely unnecessary. I did not use any of the objects that we were given. Instead, the objects took up a significant amount of space in our small dorm rooms, and we were required to retrieve them with close to zero notice (we'd get emails from Professor Cahn that said things like "I'm outside on cross campus now") which was incredibly stressful. It should be made clear that these kits are not essential so that students could choose to not pick them up, or we should have been given more notice about when the pick up windows would be. Finally, class communications could have been significantly more clear. I often had to email my TA or meet with other students in the class in order to puzzle through what the emails meant. These emails were unclear, wordy, and inconsistent. They were slightly improved from first semester, in which we truly could not figure out what was required of us, but still, instructors should attempt to write more concise, clear emails.
Truthfully, there were many issues, but there is not much anyone can do about them. The faculty for this course did an excellent job.
having some degree of break system was nice but i firmly believe that the course would be better just giving students universally a break eg having ~7 labs a semester and calling it there
I really appreciated not having lab every week because 3 hours straight on zoom can be a lot sometimes. And the TFs were generally really responsive and helpful when we had questions.
I liked all the work Sid did to make it more interactive!
I think the zoom lab succeeded, but I do wish sometimes breaks were built into the lab time.
Could have made more of an effort to curb unnecessary busy work.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes, this is a low workload lab that allows for practical understanding of concepts learned in physics lab.
No, unless you have to take it
Yes! The professors are so understanding and make the class so much fun.
yeah you have to but even then it's not a bad lab at all and completely doable in a busy semester.

Yes, I highly recommend this course. I thought it was much better than the physics lecture. Professor Cahn and Professor Barrett are incredible and extremely dedicated to providing the best learning experience for their students!
Yes, if it is necessary for your major. From what I understand, this class is a safer option compared to the other lab classes.

This course offered few perks to offset the onus of its being required for a large number of students, particularly near the end. I would recommend that a fellow student attend the class for a few weeks to determine whether or not they would be capable of soldiering on through the remainder of the semester.

I would recommend this course only if it is a requirement for their major and/or for grad school. Although the concepts I learned here were interesting and relevant to PHYS181, the virtual format of the course made it difficult to be engaged.
if required
no

Yes, I'd recommend it to people who have already taken PHYS 165. I'm not sure if the in-person lab is more stressful or demanding, but as a virtual lab I thought we got a good survey of the advertised topics. I assume most people are probably taking this lab for their major or as a premed, and I think it's well directed towards that crowd.
Yes, I would recommend this course to people who need an introductory physics lab.
I would only take it if you have to for a requirement.
I would recommend this course if it is a requirement for your major.
I would not recommend this course for another student unless it is required because the course material was not clearly taught to us. I hope that in-person physics lab is more enjoyable.
This is a really fun course with really fun professors. I'd recommend this course to anyone interested in science.
It's required so it doesn't really matter. Overall, it was too hard for students who aren'g going into physics as a career even though the instructors cared.
Yeah! Really felt like a 0.5 workload class. Hopefully they still have PLAs. I feel like I learned a lot from them :)

If you need to take a physics lab, you should take this class. It is a fair amount of work, however, it is well organized and you can learn quite a bit. That being said, if you do not need to take this class for your major, I would not recommed it.
I think most people take physics lab because they have to, so take it if you need to. First semester of physics lab is definitely better than the second semester, so keep that in mind.
if you're taking a concurrent physics lecture course and need the lab credit
I took the virtual version of this lab, and I would imagine that the experience is very different. The virtual version was kind of dull.
Yes because the professor and TA were fantastic
Yes if necessary.

Yes? It's not bad for what it is. I appreciated that they stopped doing a practical exam this semester and that the workload was more manageable than the last. This class is not hard but also not fun, and the 3 hours + spent every week were not the most enjoyable.
this semester with the break week-PLA set up was much less stressful than last semester when  we'd have multiple assignments due on the same day
Yes, I would recommend this course to a student that needs to take a physics-lab course. This class helps strengthen the concepts from 181/201.
Not unless you have to take it for your major or as a premed.
You shouldn't expect to get much out of this class except for ticking a box for applications in the future.
I would suggest taking 165L or 166L depending on which subjects are more relevant to what interests you unless you need to take both for your major.

No. Do not take this course if you do not need it for a requirement. It's a waste of time. Literally. I learned absolutely nothing and the laboratory manuals are so ambiguous. Lab notebook, write ups and PLA's were so time consuming. I learned very little for the amount of time required to do well in this course.
If this person is interested in Physics, I would suggest this class to them.
I would recommend this course to another student who needs to take it, but I cannot comment on taking it as an elective since I never actually got to perform the experiments.
Yes! Deciding to take 166L instead of 205L was definitely a stress reliever for me. I was still able to learn and apply physics lab concepts while better managing my time.
If needed, yes.
Absolutely. The professors and teaching fellows made this class a great experience.
Only if they have to take it for a requirement
Yes! Its a fun time, expecially if you are a premed.
Yes; not a stressor course but is helpful.
If it is required.
Not unless they need lab
Yes if you need physics lab for med school
yes if you need a physics lab. Can be very tedious but low workload.
No
Yes! Great intro lab
If you needed it for pre med

I would only recommend this course to students who need it as a requirement. It is not necessarily very hard, but it is pretty tedious and dry at times, but this may largely be due to the fact that it's incredibly hard to adapt lab activities to the online format. If you need it, I think the course is pretty reasonable and it is nice if you're able to collaborate with a friend on the lab notes and report.
I think that I would recommend this course only to students who need it to fulfill a requirement.
only for pre med requirements
Yes, if this is required for your major or if you want a more in depth knowledge on topics in Physics.

This course is probably mandatory if you are reading this, so just enjoy it as much as you can! The main debate is probably between this and the 205L, which would really be better paired with at least 200/201 and or for people really interested in Physics (and a bit of programming).
I would recommend it if one has to take a Physics lab, though I think the experience would be very different in person.
No, I would not because it will not teach you anything new, if you have already taken introductory physics lecture.

Yes, I would recommend this course to another student. It is a great way to understand and apply the courses taught in the intro physics classroom. The labs are very engaging and are a great supplement for PHYS 171/181.

I would recommend this course if you want to learn more about electricity and magnetism. The course mainly focuses on these topics, and you explore key concepts with data and think about applications. The teaching team cares a lot about students. However, this course sometimes felt long with some confusing concepts.

I would highly recommend this course to another student looking for a physics lab class. This class was low stress while also being a great learning opportunity. I developed my understanding of physics concepts without ever really being pressed for time or worrying about what my grade would turn out to be. I also enjoyed the collaborative nature of the class and the emphasis on succinctness.
I would recommend this course.
You probably have to take this course. Overall it is pretty solid! But some of the labs are pretty long and grading can be frustrating.
No, unless it's required.
Yes, it's pretty cool and interesting!
This class is likely a requirement for you if you are taking it.
This is a fair course as a physics lab course. The instructors try to make it as engaging as possible, so it's a fairly chill and enjoyable experience as well.
Not unless you have to take it, e.g. pre-med
Yes I think that the course is well structured
I would recommend this course to other students. It is a great way to learn more about the applications of physics.

Would not recommend if you do not need it.  It is fun, but it takes a lot of time, and the topics have high disparity in intellectual demand. So if you don't like/aren't good at a particular concept, you have to learn it to a high degree anyway.
If they need to take it as a requirement or really enjoy circuits.
If you need a lab or the distributional credit. Fine course just likely are other courses that would be more interesting if your looking for a "fun" course.
I would recommend this course because it is useful for contextualizing what you learn in physics (and because it is often required :) ).

No, but if you're reading this, you probably take it regardless. ALSO, IN SPRING 2021, THE GRADE CUTOFF FOR AN A WAS A 96.05 & FOR AN A- IT WAS A 93.0. Pre-covid, the curve is more realistic, but everyone did better during the online semester for obvious reasons. Take this into account if the course is still online when you're taking it. Good luck friends!
I would only recommend this course to someone who had to take this course as a requirement.

I would recommend this to any student pursuing a career in STEM, as it teaches you basic physical principles and how to properly create an experimental setup and take precise/accurate measurements. It also teaches you a lot about how to take skewed results into consideration and how to deal with adverse events. Overall, it is an excellent course to learn more about scientific protocol in the lab.
sure as a credit d, it's fun sometimes. really cool techniques and it's fun to work with one's hands!

I mean if you want to take it for fun- don't. It's not that exciting. But since most of us are here for a requirement it's not the absolute worst. Just try to use your resources and get out of there as fast as possible.
If you need it.
Not recommended unless for a requirement.
Yes.

I would only recommend this course if you are taking physics concurrently or like lab work. As far as STEM labs go, it is not too taxing, but I wouldn't take it on a whim unless you really want a more hands-on approach to physics.

No, unless they have to. It's one of those classes that really makes you think a lab should be worth a full credit, because the workload of this is equivalent to a class. But the bad part is that the work is boring and repetitive and you don't learn much from the labs.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We had to watch videos of professors performing experiments and attend a live 3-hour session.
n/a
Virtual lab; watched pre-recorded experiments done by the professor; utilized Physics Kits for experiments (created by Prof. Cahn)
Independent Lab assignments called PLA's which we developed and completed on our own.
Recorded lecture, live virtual lecture
do-it-yourself labs at home
Four at home "post-lab activities" we could design ourselves.
virtual lab with kits that we could use to design our own experiments at home
none
On weeks of break days we completed PLA's, or remote labs.
We had live virtual "seminars" on our designated lab days (excluding break weeks) and the lab content was delivered through pre-recorded videos.
The labs were virtual where the TA would give a short lecture or introduction on the material and students would then go into breakout rooms and work on the lab.
Live Zoom Lecture
None
Lab consisted of virtual meeting room where students worked independently on a lab handout. If there was any confusion or questions, those were adressed by unmuting and asking peers or the TA.
Physical instruments to carry out experiments
Live lab with follow along work.
In addition to virtual labs, we had post-lab activities every other week.
This course was a live discussion section where break out rooms were used to provide a collaborative environment for students to work on the labs.
kits sent to do hands on lab experiment
All live virtual lectures but had to do labs at home by ourselves as well.
VIdeos
There were live lab sessions in which we watched recorded videos of Dr. Cahn doing the lab.
N/a
Lab kits were sent to students for independent study on some assignments.
We watched videos on canvas and also had SindeyKits
n/a
None
Mixed with ta
Kits with labs
We had live virtual labs through Zoom that started with a short virtual lecture portion, and then we were sent into breakout rooms to complete the lab portion with our peers.
The lab lectures were also recorded.
NA
We watched recorded lab video.

The experiments were pre-recorded, the TA had live virtual lecture for ~10 mins each class, then the students worked on the class assignments synchronously through Zoom (usually in small breakout rooms)
They also had us perform free-form take home labs.
This class was a virtual lab where we worked in small groups in breakout rooms.

We had a virtual lab section on weeks when we did not have break days. During our lab section, we had a brief lecture by our TFs. Then, we were broken up into breakout rooms where we answered questions based on videos pertaining to lab setup and data collection. On weeks when we had break days, there was no lab section, and we completed a post-lab activity of our choice instead.
in-person and recorded lab
We had virtual lab every week except for weeks when we had break days. Those weeks, we did post-lab assignments on our own time that were then due the following week on our assigned lab day.
with recorded portions of experimentation
virtual lab with TA and section
n/a
asynchronous lab activities every other week
virtual lab only including pre-recorded and live components
We just attended the live sessions on our day.
Weeks with break weeks included asynchronous learning through individual lab projects completed on own time allowing for a break from normal lab cycle.
PLAs completed outside of class
Class consisted of virtual labs completed in groups, with the addition of individual self-designed experiments on break weeks.
n/a
recorded videos to watch during lab session or alone
No other modes of learning!
n/a
This course was mainly a weekly lab over zoom during the normal 3-hour lab slot.
